article.body: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday called on governments around the world to join the U.S. in confronting Chinaâs Communist Party leaders, saying in a fiery election-year speech that engagement with Beijing has failed. Speaking at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library in Yorba Linda, Calif., Pompeo said the bond with China that the 37th president famously sought had failed to materialize. âThe kind of engagement we have been pursuing has not brought the kind of change inside of China that President Nixon had hoped to induce,â Pompeo said. The secretaryâs speech came as tensions are flaring between Beijing and Washington in the wake of the U.S. ordering the closure of the Chinese consulate in Houston. The State Department said the move was made to protect U.S. intellectual property and private information. Read:China says its consulate in Houston has been ordered shut. China has vowed retaliation if the order isnât reversed, and the U.S. is reportedly preparing for Beijing to close one or more American consulates in China. Invoking President Ronald Reaganâs âtrust but verifyâ approach to the Soviet Union, Pompeo said: âWhen it comes to the [Chinese Communist Party], I say, we must âdistrust and verify.ââ Pompeo stressed that the U.S. would keep talking with China. But he called on âevery leader of every nationâ to âinsist on reciprocity, to insist on transparency and accountability from the Chinese Communist Party.â He also said the U.S. should âempowerâ the Chinese people, who he sought to differentiate from the party. Pompeoâs speech was the fourth in a series of addresses on China by top Trump administration officials. It comes in the thick of the U.S. presidential election campaign, in which President Donald Trump is lagging behind presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden in polls of key battleground states. Trump has accused Biden of being soft on China.
